title: Young Rich Lister Fred Schebesta leaps on open banking opportunity
text:
Ever ambitious, the 38-year-old seized on an issues paper released yesterday from a new Senate Select Committee on financial and regulatory technology into 'open banking' — a raft of reforms that require banks to share data on their customers so as to increase competition.

If enacted, he said, the reforms canvassed in the paper would allow Finder to transform itself from a company that allows customers to compare financial products, into a company that does the switching for them.

"If this enhancement of consumer data rights happens, we'll get to where a lot of start-up banks or super funds or insurers won't even need to invest in a customer-facing front-end," Schebesta said, referring to the Committee's consideration of giving accredited fintechs more power over the banking data entrusted to them by customers, so they can not only read it but can quickly switch providers on customers' behalf.

"People just want the best rate or the best deal, they want it now, and Finder can help facilitate that."

Mr Schebesta's interest in finding the best deal is perhaps a symptom of a childhood that combined privilege with privation: he attended the expensive and academically selective Sydney Grammar School, but on occasion lived in a caravan while his parents studied to be specialist doctors.

Whether financial services providers see Finder as a cheap marketing department or a necessary cost of finding new customers, there is little doubting its power as a referrer. It tracks Reserve Bank data on new credit card activations against its own referrals, and claims to be responsible for 10 per cent of all activity in some months.

Indeed Finder is so popular that it is one of the few comparison sites that in some instances can justify charging a commission on click-throughs alone rather than sales.

But while he's had early success, he rejects the 'get rich quick' ethos that might see him try to list Finder before it fulfils more of his global ambitions, which saw it expand to the US in 2015 and the UK this year.

"Finder is a real business, making profits and paying dividends, and we intend on growing it privately," he said.

"If there is a clear reason to IPO, we will. Otherwise we aren’t looking to cash in quick, unlike some of those Ponzi scheme start-ups you've seen where the share prices tanks on listing."

Michael Bailey's feature on Frank Schebesta appears on www.afr.com and inside the Young Rich issue of AFR Magazine, inside Friday's Financial Review.
description: The co-founder of Finder.com hopes consumers having more rights to their data will expand his $100 million-a-year product comparison business.
